title: As many as five Heat cuts could transition to team's D-League affiliate
text:
As many as five Heat cuts could transition to team's D-League affiliate Spoelstra says Heat cuts still can prosper with D-League afffilaite 
Erik Spoelstra says the Heat's D-League affiliate offers a potential path back to the NBA for those cut at deadline. 
Erik Spoelstra says the Heat's D-League affiliate offers a potential path back to the NBA for those cut at deadline. Ira Winderman Contact Reporter South Florida Sun Sentinel Few surprises expected with final Heat roster moves 
The formal deadline is Monday, but NBA regulations have the clock ticking far faster when it comes to the Miami Heat's roster decisions. 
Although the deadline for reducing to a 15-player roster is Monday, released players must clear the 48-waiver period before the NBA's 2015-16 salary clock begins Tuesday. 
For the Heat and most teams, that makes the deadline Saturday's 5 p.m. waiver call, with the Heat currently carrying the NBA-maximum 20 players during the preseason. 
The five cuts are expected to be formulaic, with Greg Whittington, Keith Benson and Briante Weber expected to transition to the Heat's NBA Development League team, the Sioux Falls Skyforce. Tre Kelley, another expected cut, also is positioned to join the Skyforce. The fifth cut is expected to be John Lucas III. 
Under the NBA's "affiliate-player" rule with the D-League, Whittington, Benson and Weber are expected to then be signed by the Skyforce if they are not claimed by an NBA team. Recently released guard Corey Hawkins also is expected to transition to the Skyforce as a designated Heat affiliate player, with NBA teams allowed to designate up to four such players. Such players must finalize their 2015-16 D-League commitments by Thursday. Spoelstra: No plans to tinker with starting lineup 
Erik Spoelstra says the plan is to stick with Whiteside, Deng, Bosh, Wade, Dragic as his starting five for the foreseeable future.

Because Kelley played with the Skyforce two seasons ago, he is considered a "returning-rights player" and also would be under Skyforce control if he were to elect to play in the D-League this season. 
The Heat's other roster decision figures to come down to second-year forward James Ennis, whose contract becomes fully guaranteed for the season if he is on the Heat roster on opening night, Wednesday at AmericanAirlines Arena against the Charlotte Hornets. 
With the Heat operating above the NBA luxury tax, it is possible that they open the season with only 14 players. 
Among the reasons for the Heat's expected quick action at Saturday's waiver deadline is that a player not waived by then but later cut would receive 1/170th of his NBA salary per day starting Tuesday, when the NBA begins regular-season play. The NBA operates on a 170-day regular-season salary calendar.
